questions.question: ………………….. on tip-toes, she reached for the mango.
questions.description: She stood on tip-toes. She reached for the mango. We can combine these two sentences using the present participle.

questions.question: …………………….. hungry, the child ate the food greedily.
questions.description: The child was hungry. The child ate the food greedily. We can combine these two sentences using being. Being hungry, the child ate the food greedily.

questions.question: ……………………….. his injury, he played exceptionally well.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition. It is followed by an ing form or noun.

questions.question: ……………………. injured his knee, he cannot walk.
…………………………. himself in deep debt, he lost all hope.
In the event of such a thing ………………………, I will resign.
He did not lose hope ……………………….. his repeated failures.
questions.description: All of these are possible here.

questions.question: …………………………. taking the tablet, I didn’t get any relief.
………………………. pity for the mouse, the seer turned it into a beautiful girl.
………………………….. tired, I lay down to sleep.
questions.description: I was tired. I lay down to sleep. We can combine these two sentences using being.

questions.question: …………………….. much blood, he struggled to stay awake.
God ………………………., we shall meet again.
Never ……………………. seen so much food.
questions.description: When a sentence begins with a negative expression, the inverted word order is used.

questions.question: I look forward to …………………… from you.
questions.description: The ing form is used after look forward to.

questions.question: The faster you run, ………………………. you get tired.
questions.description: In both clauses, we use the structure the + comparative + clause.

questions.question: ………………….. our best efforts, we could not win the contract.
questions.description: You can use despite or in spite of here.

questions.question: It is time you ………………….. married.
questions.description: The simple past is used with a present or future meaning after it is time.

questions.question: I am extremely close to ………………………… friends I have.
questions.description: The few means not many but all of them.

questions.question: Having …………………… the cats, she went to work.
She speaks …………………………. she knows everything.
questions.description: Either as if or as though is possible here.

questions.question: ……………………….. I didn’t know his address, I couldn’t write to him.
questions.description: As gives the reason so shows the effect.

questions.question: You …………………….. start spending more wisely.
questions.description: Had better is used to give strong advice.

questions.question: I would rather you ……………………. seeing her.
questions.description: A simple past is used after would rather to refer to the present or future.

questions.question: He worked …………………….. hard that he fell ill.
questions.description: Use so before an adjective and such before adjective + noun.

questions.question: I always feel ............................... in the afternoon.
questions.description: Feel is a copular verb. We use adjectives to modify copular verbs.

questions.question: I .............................. her till twelve, and then went home.
questions.description: Before an object, we use wait for.

questions.question: They talk such ...............................!
questions.description: Nonsense is uncountable. It cannot be used with a.

questions.question: Every one of the guests .............................. dancing.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after every one.

questions.question: I go there every ...............................
questions.description: Every should be followed by a singular noun.

questions.question: I see her every few ..................................
questions.description: Every is used with plural nouns in expressions that refer to intervals.

questions.question: I enjoy ............................... in the rain.
questions.description: Enjoy is followed by an ing form.

questions.question: It was Sam ............................... bought the tickets.
questions.description: That cannot be used to refer to people in non-identifying relative clauses.

questions.question: She looks ........................... older than she used to.
questions.description: Very cannot be used with comparatives.

questions.question: We ................................ meet in the cafeteria in the evenings.
questions.description: Either would or used to can be used to talk about past habits.

questions.question: Let's meet ............................... next week.
questions.description: Sometime refers to an indefinite time in future.

questions.question: It is time you ………………………… that mole checked.
questions.description: A simple past is used after it is time to refer to the present or future.

questions.question: There …………………………… be a tea stall in that corner.
questions.description: Used to can be used to talk about past states. Would cannot be used with this meaning.

questions.question: He …………………………… to be a singer.
questions.description: Use the simple present to talk about needs, wants, desires, aspirations etc.

questions.question: You ………………………….. never violate the rules.
questions.description: Must shows strong obligation.

questions.question: If she left home at six, she ……………………………… be here soon.
questions.description: Should shows logical possibility.

questions.question: There are no secrets between you and …………………………….
questions.description: Between is a preposition. A pronoun used after the preposition should be in its object form.

questions.question: She patted ………………………… on the back for completing the project on time.
questions.description: When the subject and object refer to the same person, the reflexive pronoun (herself, yourself etc.) is used instead of the object pronoun.

questions.question: I waited ………………………… hours and then I went home.
questions.description: For is used with duration.

questions.question: ………………………………. playing to the best of our ability, we could not win the match.
questions.description: Either despite or in spite of can be used here.

questions.question: They congratulated her …………………………………. her success.
questions.description: Either for or on is possible here.

questions.question: Why are you always shouting ………………………….. me?
…………………………….. of them was there.
questions.description: All and some should be followed by a plural verb.

questions.question: 'I haven't turned in the assignment ‘………………………….. have I.’
questions.description: After a negative remark, we can add another negative remark to it with neither or nor.

questions.question: She is ........................... cute.
questions.description: We do not use so much to modify adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: She worked hard so that she ................................. more.
I waited for ........................... two hours and then I went home.
questions.description: We can use another with plural expressions of quantity.

questions.question: I call my mother ..............................
questions.description: Everyday means ordinary or typical. Every day means each day.

questions.question: My ………………………………  too heavy.
questions.description: Luggage does not have a plural form.

questions.question: Either Sam or Peter .............................. to bring the violin.
questions.description: Use a singular verb when two singular nouns are connected by either/or.

questions.question: I would rather you .................................... talking to her.
questions.description: Use a past tense after would rather to refer to the future.

questions.question: At least 10 people ................................... in the explosion.
questions.description: A passive verb is required here.

questions.question: A number of people .................................. to migrate.
questions.description: Use a plural verb after a number of use the simple present to talk about facts.

questions.question: The number of people who want to migrate ................................. on the rise.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after the number of.

questions.question: I ……………………….. a call from him in the morning.
questions.description: The past simple is more common with expressions like in the morning.

questions.question: He told me what ……………………
questions.description: The past perfect is more appropriate to talk about the earlier of two past events.

questions.question: If I had gone to university, I ……………………… an attorney.
questions.description: In the third conditional we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: I heard them ………………………. in the other room.
questions.description: Either the gerund or the infinitive without to is possible here.

questions.question: I would rather you ……………………… another job.
questions.description: The simple past is used after would rather.

questions.question: It is high time he ……………………. smoking.
questions.description: The past simple is used after it is high time.

questions.question: When I met him yesterday I ……………………… him about my problems.
He was acquitted ………………………. the charges levelled against him.
We reached the theatre after the movie ………………………..
questions.description: The past perfect is used for the earlier of the two past actions.

questions.question: I waited for him but he ………………………….
You haven’t returned the vacuum cleaner you …………………….. from me.
………………….. the footsteps, the thief ran away.
questions.description: The present participle is used to combine two clauses when they refer to actions that happen simultaneously.

questions.question: The poor man ……………………. very hungry ate the food greedily.
……………………….. his muscle power, he was defeated by his opponent.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition. Use it before a noun.

questions.question: ……………………. a cripple, he cannot walk.
questions.description: He is a cripple. He cannot walk. Here we can replace is with being and write 'Being a cripple, he cannot walk.'

questions.question: …………………………. himself in deep debt, he decided to sell his home.
questions.description: He found himself in deep debt. He decided to sell his home. We can connect these two sentences using finding.

questions.question: In the event of such a thing ………………………, I will quit.
He intends to make another attempt ……………………….. his repeated failures.
questions.description: Either despite or notwithstanding can be used here.

questions.question: …………………………. my best efforts, I could not succeed.
………………………. pity for the mouse, the magician turned it into a cat.
………………………….. dissatisfied, he resigned his job.
questions.description: He was dissatisfied. He resigned his job. We can replace was with being. Being dissatisfied, he resigned his job.

questions.question: …………………….. the message, he departed.
questions.description: When one action follows another action, we can express that idea with a perfect participle.

questions.question: I will be staying here for ……………………… more days.
questions.description: A few indicates a small number.

questions.question: He is junior …………………………… me.
questions.description: The words junior and senior are followed by to.

questions.question: China is ………………………… than India.
questions.description: Use a comparative expression before than.

questions.question: He is ………………………….. than her.
questions.description: Younger is the comparative form of young.

questions.question: I gave the kitten …………………………… milk.
questions.description: Use little with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Of the two routes, this is ………………………………
questions.description: Use the comparative form when a group consists of just two people or things.

questions.question: We got ……………………………….. rain this year. The crops are all dying.
questions.description: Little means hardly any.

questions.question: This material is superior ………………………….. that.
questions.description: Use to after superior and inferior.

questions.question: He is ……………………………… of the four men.
questions.description: The superlative is used to compare a person or thing with the group to which they/it belong(s).

questions.question: I do not earn as much as …………………………… does.
questions.description: The subject form is used before a verb.

questions.question: A dog is ……………………………… than a cat.
Hindi ………………………….. in many parts of India.
His parents ………………………… when he was a child.
questions.description: Died is the past tense of die.

questions.question: He was declared ……………………….. on arrival.
questions.description: Dead is an adjective. Died is a verb.

questions.question: I ………………………… in
questions.description: The simple past is used when we say when something happened.

questions.question: Let’s ……………………………. your plans.
questions.description: Discuss is one of those verbs that are not followed by a preposition.

questions.question: Though she was in town, she didn’t ………………………… a visit.
You haven’t …………………………… for the drinks.
questions.description: Paid is the past participle of pay.

questions.question: She is looking forward …………………………… a grandmother.
questions.description: Write to + ing form after look forward.

questions.question: …………………………. big city New York is!
questions.description: Use what a before a noun + adjective.

questions.question: She didn’t tell me where …………………………. that night.
questions.description: The inverted word order is not used in indirect questions.

questions.question: You ……………………… stop smoking.
If you applied in time, you …………………………… the job.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would/could + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If I know the answer, I …………………………… tell you.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: ………………………… your shoes off.
questions.description: The simple present is used in imperative sentence.

questions.question: She ……………………………. younger than her elder sister.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about facts.

questions.question: How did you ………………………… then?
questions.description: The infinitive without to is used after do, does and did.

questions.question: ……………………… forget to close the door when you leave.
questions.description: The simple present is used in imperative sentences. In imperatives the subject is you.

questions.question: The cop asked him what he ………………………………… doing there.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: I …………………………… my mother every day.
questions.description: Use the simple present to talk about habits.

questions.question: The cat ……………………………. her litter.
questions.description: Has had is in the present perfect tense. The present perfect is used to give news.

questions.question: They ………………………….. by now.
If we do not take precautions, we …………………………….. in trouble.
questions.description: In the first conditional, use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: I ………………………………. her since our school days.
questions.description: We use the present perfect to talk about life experiences up to now.

questions.question: Somebody wanted a drink, …………………………….?
questions.description: They is used in question tags after somebody, anybody, nobody.

questions.question: I would rather you …………………………… talking to her.
questions.description: The past tense is used in this construction.

questions.question: I have ……………………. doubts.
questions.description: Use a few to refer to a small number.

questions.question: She is junior ………………………… me.
questions.description: Use to after junior, senior, inferior, superior etc.

questions.question: No other language is  ……………………….. as Chinese.
questions.description: Use the positive adjective in the construction as...as...

questions.question: This is ……………………. than that.
questions.description: Cheaper is the comparative form of cheap.

questions.question: …………………………… knowledge is always a dangerous thing.
questions.description: A little indicates a small quantity.

questions.question: Of the two routes, this is ……………………………
questions.description: The comparative is used to speak of two things.

questions.question: I have ……………………… knowledge of politics.
questions.description: Little knowledge means almost no knowledge.

questions.question: This material is superior ……………………………… that.
questions.description: Use to instead of than after superior, inferior etc.

questions.question: He is ……………………………… of the three brothers.
questions.description: The superlative is used to compare one person or thing with the whole group to which they belong.

questions.question: We are not as rich as ……………………………
questions.description: Object pronouns are more common after as and than.

questions.question: Man is …………………………… animal.
……………………….. Indians speak English.
questions.description: Use many before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: …………………………… his poor vision, he can read books.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition. Use it before a noun or an ing form.

questions.question: …………………………. his popularity, he failed to win the election.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition. Use it before a preposition.

questions.question: …………………………… rich he may be, he still wants more.
questions.description: However rich he may be means 'it doesn't matter how rich he is'.

questions.question: ………………………….. he grew, the more cautious he became.
questions.description: Use the comparative form in both clauses.

questions.question: The more they laughed at him, ……………………………. he became.
questions.description: Angrier is the comparative form of angry.

questions.question: …………………………… my friend saw me, he stopped the car.
……………………………. you drop the glass, it will break.
questions.description: If expresses a condition.

questions.question: The soldiers fought with ………………………… courage that the enemy suffered a crushing defeat.
…………………………… you want more money, you have to do more work.
He is ………………………….. ill that the doctors do not expect him to recover.
questions.description: So...that... shows cause and effect.

questions.question: She is ………………………….. shy to address a gathering.
Take a guide with you …………………………… you do not lose your way.
questions.description: So that expresses purpose.

questions.question: We went …………………………… in the morning.
questions.description: There is no preposition in the expression go swimming, go walking, go climbing etc.

questions.question: Let’s ……………………….. something.
questions.description: Let is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: I went …………………….. Canada to meet my brother.
questions.description: Use to to show direction.

questions.question: She went dancing ……………………….. the room.
I have invited all of my friends ……………………. my party.
questions.description: You are invited to a specific event.

questions.question: You .................... get some rest.
questions.description: Had better is used to give strong advice.

questions.question: One of my cousins ……………………… a singer.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after one of.

questions.question: The teacher had scarcely left the class ………………………. the children started talking.
questions.description: Scarcely is followed by when or before.

questions.question: No sooner had I opened the door, …………………….. the cat jumped out.
questions.description: We use than after no sooner.

questions.question: I was hardly inside the house ……………………… it started raining.
questions.description: Hardly is followed by when or before.

questions.question: How about …………………….. a drink?
questions.description: Use an ing form after how about and what about.

questions.question: She accused me ...................... stealing her watch.
I want to know why ………………………….. late.
questions.description: In indirect questions, the subject goes before the verb.

questions.question: If she had asked me, I …………………………….. her.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: She would have come if you …………………………….. her.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: We are looking forward ……………………………. you.
questions.description: Write to + ing form after look forward/looking forward.

questions.question: The more you praise him the more arrogant …………………………..
questions.description: The same pattern is used in both clauses.

questions.question: The louder you speak ………………………………. you confuse me.
questions.description: The + comparative is used in both clauses.

questions.question: Would you mind …………………………… me your pen?
questions.description: Ing forms or if-clauses are used after would you mind.

questions.question: …………………………… you study well, you cannot pass.
questions.description: If is grammatically correct in that sentence, but it does not make logical sense.

questions.question: This boy is ………………………… to work.
questions.description: Note the pattern too...to...

questions.question: If I were the king, you ………………………………. my queen.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use past simple in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: She is very fond ……………………………. her cats and dogs.
He enjoys ……………………………….. with children.
questions.description: Write an ing form after enjoy.

questions.question: You will not succeed …………………………. you work really hard.
questions.description: Unless means if not.

questions.question: I have worked in this office ………………………… twenty years.
questions.description: Use for with duration.

questions.question: She accused me ……………………………… poisoning her cat.
He left ten minutes …………………………..
questions.description: Ago is used to count back from the present.

questions.question: …………………………. you follow your doctor’s advice, you will get well soon.
questions.description: If expresses a condition.

questions.question: Martha along with her friends ……………………………. arrived.
questions.description: When two nouns are connected with and, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: What …………………………. you do then?
questions.description: The word then shows distance in time. Hence, a past tense is used here.

questions.question: The boy has been missing …………………….. Monday.
questions.description: Use since with the starting point.

questions.question: It ………………………. a hot day, I didn’t go out.
One of the hens ……………………………… missing.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after one of.

questions.question: Neither John nor his wife ………………………… there.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after neither/nor.

questions.question: He is collecting money for …………………………..
questions.description: The homeless means all homeless people.

questions.question: ‘I can’t speak French.’ ‘……………………. can I.’
questions.description: Neither/nor + auxiliary + subject can be used to make a negative addition to a negative statement.

questions.question: You are ………………………… generous.
questions.description: Either very or so can be used here.

questions.question: We reserved the table in advance so that we …………………………. to wait.
She has bought ……………………………. car.
questions.description: Another can mean different or an extra.

questions.question: Where is ……………………………… book you borrowed from me?
Trains run ………………………….. ten minutes.
questions.description: Every can be used before plural expressions in measurements of frequency.

questions.question: Manali is famous for its beautiful …………………………..
questions.description: Scenery does not have a plural form.

questions.question: Sania and Rohan …………………………….. arrived.
questions.description: When two singular subjects are connected by and, they should be followed by a plural verb.

questions.question: The principal as well as the teachers …………………………. present at the meeting.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with as well as, the verb agrees with the former in number and person.

questions.question: The mother along with her daughters …………………………….. outside.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with along with, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: Between you and ………………………….., there are no secrets.
questions.description: A pronoun used as the object of a preposition should be in its object form.

questions.question: Start at once, so that you ……………………………. miss the train.
We went …………………………… on the weekend.
questions.description: There is no preposition in the expression go swimming, go walking, go climbing etc.

questions.question: Let’s go ………………………… if you aren't busy.
questions.description: This is a common expression referring to leisure activities.

questions.question: I went swimming ………………………… the river.
questions.description: Prepositions of place are used after go + …ing.

questions.question: Why did you go skating ...................... that lake? You could have killed yourself.
We went ...................... Canada last year.
questions.description: To shows direction.

questions.question: You .................... give me my money back.
One of my cousins ……………………… abroad.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after one of.

questions.question: I was scarcely inside the house ………………………. the kids started screaming.
questions.description: Scarcely is followed by when or before.

questions.question: No sooner had I put the phone down, ................... it started ringing again.
questions.description: We use than after no sooner.

questions.question: She had hardly stepped out ..................... it started pouring.
Why sit down when you can ....................... down?
questions.description: To lie down is to recline.

questions.question: She accused me of ...................... to her.
questions.description: To lie is to make a false statement.

questions.question: There ……………………… an explosion in the city.
questions.description: When there is no time reference, we use the present perfect to talk about finished events.

questions.question: The terrorists …………………………. the bridge.
questions.description: To blow  something up is to cause it to explode.

questions.question: We …………………………. the job by next Monday.
questions.description: The future perfect is used to say that an action will have been completed by a particular point of time in future.

questions.question: She ………………………… by the time I reached her place.
questions.description: The past perfect is used for the earlier of two past actions.

questions.question: He didn’t let me …………………………..
questions.description: Let is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: You haven’t …………………….. for your drinks.
questions.description: Paid is the past participle of pay.

questions.question: The firemen were called in to ………………………… the fire
questions.description: To put out is to extinguish.

questions.question: How beautifully …………………………..!
questions.description: In exclamations, the subject goes before the verb.

questions.question: Tell me what ………………………… in my room.
questions.description: In indirect questions, the auxiliary goes after the subject.

questions.question: You ……………………… not pick up a fight with him.
questions.description: Had better is used to give strong advice.

questions.question: We started early so that we ………………………. miss the bus.
That dog of ………………………… has bitten me again.
……………………….. he comes in time, we will not be able to meet him.
questions.description: Unless expresses a condition. It is similar to if not.

questions.question: …………………………. on tip-toe, he reached for the mango.
Sam, ………………………… was my student many years ago, is now an accomplished cardiologist.
questions.description: In non-identifying relatives clauses, that cannot be used.

questions.question: ………………………… a noise, the cat ran away.
questions.description: The cat heard a noise. The cat ran away. We can combine these two with a present participle.

questions.question: …………………………. hard you work, you will not be able to finish this job.
questions.description: However means it doesn't matter how.

questions.question: The faster you run, ………………………… you get tired.
The mangoes ………………………. I bought yesterday were sour.
questions.description: In identifying relative clauses, both which and that can refer to things.

questions.question: If he had listened to my advice, he ……………………………. in trouble.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: The more you study, ………………………….. you remember.
questions.description: In both clauses we use the + comparative.

questions.question: Uma with ………………………… I went to Beijing is a rich girl.
………………………… their best efforts, they could not save her.
questions.description: Despite is a preposition. It is followed by a noun/noun phrase.

questions.question: ……………………….. you are honest, I will trust you.
questions.description: Since gives the reason.

questions.question: No sooner did the plane land ……………………. there was a loud explosion.
questions.description: No sooner is a comparative expression use than after it.

questions.question: The germ is ……………………….. small to be seen with the eye.
questions.description: Note the pattern too..to..

questions.question: You must take the tablets ………………………….. get well.
questions.description: To and in order to show purpose.

questions.question: ............................ did the hunter raise his gun than the birds flew away.
…………………………. I had no ticket, I was able to get in.
questions.description: Although is similar to but in meaning.

questions.question: Don’t talk …………………………. they are singing.
questions.description: While can be used to talk about two simultaneous events.

questions.question: People live ………………………… the climate is good.
She is too intelligent ……………………. be fooled.
…………………………. my exams are over, I am free.
…………………………… she was sleeping, I left without meeting her.
questions.description: Since shows the reason.

questions.question: …………………………. carefully you drive, accidents can still happen.
questions.description: However means it doesn't matter how.

questions.question: The hall is  ……………………….. to accommodate all guests.
She is a ………………………… old lady.
questions.description: Respectable means worthy of respect.

questions.question: He is very …………………………. I am sure he will succeed in life.
questions.description: Industrious means skillful.

questions.question: You must learn to …………………………. yourself to changing circumstances.
questions.description: To adapt is to adjust.

questions.question: How long have you ………………………. in bed?
questions.description: Lain is the past participle of to lie.

questions.question: The project will require a …………………………….. amount of money.
questions.description: Considerable means huge.

questions.question: He was ……………………………. and lent me his car when I requested him to.
questions.description: Considerate means thoughtful of others' feelings.

questions.question: The speech was …………………………… uninspiring.
The soldiers fired …………………………….. causing several civilians to die.
questions.description: Indiscriminately means thoughtlessly.

questions.question: She sat there, deep in …………………………….
A good leader should be …………………………………
He is a …………………………… criminal.
questions.description: A convicted criminal is one who is found guilty of committing a crime.

questions.question: The view from the window was ……………………………
questions.description: Expansive means having a wide range.

questions.question: He ……………………… a song at the party.
I ……………………… a letter yesterday.
questions.description: The simple past is used with definite past time expressions.

questions.question: Why don’t you ………………………… me?
questions.description: Before an object, we use listen.

questions.question: Always ………………………… the truth.
questions.description: Speak is often used for one way communication.

questions.question: He ………………………… to me since the last meeting.
questions.description: The present perfect is used to talk about time up to now.

questions.question: They ……………………….. the whole matter.
questions.description: Discuss is one of those verbs that are not followed by a preposition.

questions.question: He lost the watch shortly after he …………………………. it.
questions.description: The simple past and present perfect are possible here.

questions.question: We ………………………. tennis every day.
questions.description: The simple present is used to talk about routines and habits.

questions.question: The quality of the mangoes we bought …………………………… not good.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular noun quality.

questions.question: One of my sisters …………………………. abroad.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular expression one.

questions.question: Neither of them …………………………. here at the moment.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after neither and either.

questions.question: More than one …………………………… absent today.
You will not get the book ………………………… you make the payment in advance.
questions.description: Unless means if...not...

questions.question: We have lived in this town …………………………. twenty five years.
questions.description: For is used with a duration of time.

questions.question: He was accused ………………………….. stealing.
My grandmother died ten years ………………………….
questions.description: Ago is used to count back from the present.

questions.question: You won’t get well …………………………… you take the medicine.
Susie along with her children ……………………………. come.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with along with, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: When did you ……………………………. work yesterday?
questions.description: The first form of the verb is used after do, does and did.

questions.question: He ……………………………….. ill for more than a month.
questions.description: Perfect tenses are used with for and since.

questions.question: Yesterday …………………………. a holiday, I went to watch a movie.
One of the boys ………………………………… not submitted his work.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after one of.

questions.question: Neither James nor Sam …………………………… at the wedding.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after neither and nor.

questions.question: He provided …………………………….. with food.
questions.description: The poor means all poor people.

questions.question: ‘I haven’t got a ticket.’ ‘………………………….. have I.’
You are …………………………… generous.
questions.description: We do not use so much to modify adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: Start at once, so that you …………………………… there by noon.
I want to stay for …………………………. two weeks.
questions.description: We can use another with plural expressions of quantity.

questions.question: I visit my parents every …………………………..
questions.description: Every can be used before plural expressions in measurements of frequency.

questions.question: My ……………………………… sent to Paris by mistake.
questions.description: Baggage does not have a plural form.

questions.question: Alice and James ……………………………. going to be late.
questions.description: When two singular subjects are connected by and, the verb is singular.

questions.question: The Prime Minister as well as his ministers ………………………….. tough financial measures.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with as well as, the verb agrees with the former.

questions.question: Ten people lost ………………………………… in the accident.
A number of people …………………………… to buy cars.
questions.description: Plural verbs are common after a number of.

questions.question: Two thousand dollars ………………………… a large sum.
The team ……………………………. going to lose.
questions.description: In British English, collective nouns can be used with either singular or plural verbs in American English, singular verbs are preferred.

questions.question: No sooner had I seen the huge boulder lying in the middle of the road, ………………….. I stopped the car.
questions.description: Sooner is a comparative word use than after it.

questions.question: It is high time we ………………….. the police.
questions.description: After it is high time, we use a past tense with a present meaning.

questions.question: What is the feminine gender of fox?
………………………. knowledge is a dangerous thing.
…………………….. is the best form of flattery.
She told him a story. Identify the direct object.
He showed me his possessions. Identify the indirect object.
questions.description: The indirect object is the person who receives something.

questions.question: One of the wheels of the car ……………………… punctured.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular expression one.

questions.question: The spider was busy …………………….. web.
A shoal of …………………..
He drives very carefully. Here very is an ……………………
questions.description: Very modifies the adjective carefully. Only an adverb can modify an adjective.

questions.question: When I visited him yesterday, he ………………………..
She attended the party, …………………?
questions.description: Add a negative tag after an affirmative statement.

questions.question: The horse drew the carriage. Change into passive.
questions.description: In the simple past, the passive forms are made with 'was/were + past participle form of the verb'.
answers: The carriage is drawn by the horse
The carriage was drawn by the horse.

questions.question: Sam asked us, ‘Are you leaving today?’ Change into indirect speech
questions.description: We use whether or if to report questions.
answers: Sam asked us were we leaving that day.
Sam asked us whether we are leaving that day.
Sam asked us whether we were leaving that day.

questions.question: I feel happy whenever she ………………… at me.
I will be happy if she ………………….. at me.
questions.description: In the first conditional, use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: Too many cooks ………………….. the broth.
The voice of the protestors …………………… 	quite loud.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular noun voice, so write is.

questions.question: What is the plural form of runner up?
I realized that I ………………….. a mistake.
questions.description: Use the past perfect to indicate that something had happened before another action or situation commenced.

questions.question: Give the word that is opposite in meaning to 'moist'.
What does via media mean?
The children sat …………………….. the ground.
questions.description: To indicate position on the surface, use on.

questions.question: There was hardly ……………………………. in the box.
questions.description: Hardly anything means more or less the same as nothing.

questions.question: ………………………….. his carelessness, he scored good marks.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition it is used before nouns.

questions.question: …………………………… gets the job will have a lot of work to do.
questions.description: Whoever means it doesn’t matter who.

questions.question: ……………………………. he was young and inexperienced, he fought bravely.
questions.description: Though is used to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: He is …………………………….. to pass the test.
questions.description: When enough modifies an adjective or adverb, it goes after that adjective or adverb.

questions.question: The coffee was …………………………….. hot that it burnt my tongue.
questions.description: The pattern is so...that...

questions.question: He prefers reading books ……………………………. watching TV.
She was …………………………… angry to speak to me.
…………………………. she has taken her examination, she is waiting for the results.
He will neither spend his money ……………………………. invest it.
…………………………… he is not educated, he has great practical wisdom.
questions.description: Although is a conjunction used to connect two contrasting ideas.

questions.question: ………………………….. you keep quiet, you will be sent out of the class.
questions.description: Unless means if not.

questions.question: Everything ...................... he said was wrong.
questions.description: After quantifiers like all, every and everything, we prefer that to which.

questions.question: ...................... she said made me angry.
questions.description: What means the things which.

questions.question: Everybody .......................... arrived.
questions.description: After expressions like every, everyone and everybody we use a singular verb.

questions.question: If you ................. happen to finish early, give me a ring.
questions.description: We use should happen in the if-clause to suggest that something is very unlikely.

questions.question: If she should be late, we .................... have to leave without her.
questions.description: Would is uncommon in the main clause after 'if...should'.

questions.question: The thing ........................ happened next horrified me.
My jeans ....................... too tight for me.
questions.description: The noun jeans is plural and has no singular form.

questions.question: A lot of social problems ........................... caused by poverty.
questions.description: If the noun following 'a lot of' is plural, we use a plural verb.

questions.question: A lot of time ............................ required to learn a language.
questions.description: If the noun following 'a lot of' is singular, we use a singular verb.

questions.question: 'We have got only two liters of milk left.' '............................. not enough.'
questions.description: When we talk about amounts and quantities, we often use singular verbs.

questions.question: You are too ....................... to be a soldier.
questions.description: We use small to refer to size.

questions.question: It was ...................... hot that we stopped playing.
questions.description: Very and too cannot be followed by a that-clause.

questions.question: I have always …………….. play games well.
questions.description: Can and could have no infinitives or participles. For example, there are no forms like I have could ….

questions.question: He has always …………….. to do what he wanted.
questions.description: Can and could have no infinitives or participles. For example, there are no forms like I have could ….

questions.question: One cannot help but …………….. his courage.
questions.description: The infinitive is used without to in the structure cannot help but..

questions.question: …………….do you want a holiday?
questions.description: We use how much in questions about degree.

questions.question: I will have tea …………… coffee.
questions.description: As a preposition, instead is used with of.

questions.question: They often go fishing …………….. going to school.
questions.description: Instead of is used when a person, thing or action replaces another.

questions.question: Stella often goes to the movies …………… telling her parents.
I am interested ……………….. what she did with that money.
questions.description: Interested + ing and interested + infinitive can both be used to talk about a wish to find out something.

questions.question: At no time …………….. aware of what was happening.
questions.description: If a negative expression comes at the beginning of a clause, it is usually followed by auxiliary verb + subject.

questions.question: Only then ………….. understand what he meant.
questions.description: If a negative expression comes at the beginning of a clause, it is usually followed by auxiliary verb + subject.

questions.question: I wondered what time …………….
questions.description: In indirect questions the subject goes before the verb.

questions.question: I tried …………… the doctor but my hands were numb.
questions.description: We can use either an infinitive or an ing form after 'try' to talk about making an effort to do something.
